''Dewan Bandaraya Kuala Lumpur'' | native_name = | transcription_name = | legislature = | coa_pic = Dbkl_logo.gif | coa_res = 250px | coa_alt = | house_type = Local authority | body = Kuala Lumpur | houses = | leader1_type = Mayor of Kuala Lumpur | leader1 = [[Ahmad Fuad Ismail]] | party1 = | election1 = | structure1 = | structure1_res = | structure2 = | structure2_res = | political_groups1 = | political_groups2 = | committees1 = | committees2 = | joint_committees = | session_room = Kuala Lumpur City Hall, Kuala Lumpur.jpg | session_res = 200px | session_alt = | meeting_place = Kuala Lumpur City Hall building at [[Jalan Raja Laut]] | website = | footnotes = }} '''Kuala Lumpur City Hall''' ({{lang-ms|Dewan Bandaraya Kuala Lumpur}}, '''DBKL''') is the local authority charged with the administration of [[Kuala Lumpur]]. It is an agency under the [[Ministry of the Federal Territories (Malaysia)|Federal Territories Ministry of Malaysia]]. DBKL is responsible for public health and sanitation, waste removal and management, town planning, environmental protection and building control, social and economic development and general maintenance functions of urban infrastructure. Executive power lies with the mayor in the city hall, who is appointed for three years by the [[Ministry of the Federal Territories (Malaysia)|Federal Territories Minister]] since local government elections were suspended in 1970.{{cite news|url=http://www.citymayors.com/government/malaysia_government.html|title=Malaysia's towns and cities are governed by appointed mayors|year=2006|publisher=City Mayors|accessdate=2006-10-09}} The current mayor of Kuala Lumpur is [[Ahmad Fuad Ismail]], who has been in office since December 14, 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.dbkl.gov.my/v6/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=123&Itemid=29&lang=en|title=About KL City Hall - History|publisher=Kuala Lumpur City Hall|accessdate=2010-09-18}} The headquarters of DBKL is the Kuala Lumpur City Hall building at [[Jalan Raja Laut]]. DBKL has another office building, Menara DBKL 3 at [[Jalan Raja Abdullah]] as well as 15 branch offices around KL. == History == The agency was formerly known as '''Kuala Lumpur Municipal Council''' ([[Malay language|Malay]]: '''Majlis Bandaran Kuala Lumpur'''). During British colonial times and early independence, KL was the capital of the state of [[Selangor]]. Kuala Lumpur later achieved [[Cities of Malaysia|city status]] in 1972,{{cite web|title=Destinations: Kuala Lumpur|url=http://travel.tourism.gov.my/consumer/destinations/history.asp?state=kl|publisher=Tourism Malaysia|accessdate=2007-12-16}} becoming the first settlement in Malaysia to be granted the status after independence. Later, on February 1, 1974, Kuala Lumpur became a [[Federal Territory (Malaysia)|Federal Territory]].{{cite web|publisher=Columbia University Press|url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1E1-KualaLum.html|title=Kuala Lumpur|work=Columbia Encyclopedia, Sixth Edition 2007|accessdate=2007-12-06}} Kuala Lumpur ceased to be the capital of [[Selangor]] in 1978 after the city of [[Shah Alam]] was declared as the new state capital.{{cite web|title=Sejarah Shah Alam|language=Malay|url=http://www.mbsa.gov.my/mbsa/shah%20alam/sejarah.htm|publisher=Shah Alam City Council|accessdate=2007-12-14 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071026082733/http://www.mbsa.gov.my/mbsa/shah+alam/sejarah.htm |archivedate = October 26, 2007}} Kuala Lumpur was administered by a [[corporation sole]] called the Federal Capital Commissioner from April 1, 1961 until it was awarded city status in 1972, after which executive power was transferred to the [[Lord Mayor]] ([[Malay language|Malay]]:''Datuk Bandar'').{{cite web|url=http://www.kwp.gov.my/cmsen/3rdLevel.asp?catid=7&parentid=268&contentid=269|title=Kuala Lumpur City Hall|publisher=Ministry of Federal Territories and Urban Wellbeing|accessdate=2010-09-18}} Executive power lies with the mayor in the city hall, who is appointed for three years by the [[Ministry of the Federal Territories (Malaysia)|Federal Territories Minister]]. This system of appointing the mayor has been in place ever since the local government elections were suspended in 1970.{{cite news|url=http://www.citymayors.com/government/malaysia_government.html|title=Malaysia's towns and cities are governed by appointed mayors|year=2006|publisher=City Mayors|accessdate=2006-10-09}} On 14 May 1990, Kuala Lumpur celebrated 100 years of local authority. The new [[Flag of Kuala Lumpur|Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur flag]] and anthem were introduced. ===Lord Mayor of Kuala Lumpur=== Since 1972, the city has been led by nine mayors. The current mayor of Kuala Lumpur is [[Ahmad Fuad Ismail]], who has been in office since December 14, 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.dbkl.gov.my/v6/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=123&Itemid=29&lang=en|title=About KL City Hall - History|publisher=Kuala Lumpur City Hall|accessdate=2010-09-18}} The previous mayors are listed as below: {| class="wikitable" |- !#||Name of Mayors||In office |- |1.||[[Malay titles|Tan Sri Dato']] [[Lokman Yusof]]||1972 |- |2.||[[Malay titles|Tan Sri]] [[Yaacob Latiff]]||1973 - 1983 |- |3.||[[Malay titles|Tan Sri Dato']] [[Elyas Omar]]||1983 - 1992 |- |4.||[[Malay titles|Dato']] Dr. Mazlan Ahmad||1992 - 1995 |- |5.||Tan Sri Datoâ Kamaruzzaman Shariff||1995 - 2001 |- |6.||[[Malay titles|Dato']] Mohmad Shaid Mohd Taufek||2001 - 2004 |- |7.||Dato' Ruslin Hasan||2004 - 2006 |- |8.||Dato' Ab.
